​​where the notations are defined in Table I.
The derivation for problem transformation is given in Appendix A.
The other notations are consistent with those in Table I.

Given fixed 𝐛𝐛\bf{b}, {𝐚k}subscript𝐚𝑘\{{\bf{a}}_{k}\} and 𝐟𝐟\bf{f}, the objective (10a) is a function of 𝚯𝚯\bf{\Theta}, denoted by f0​(𝚯)subscript𝑓0𝚯f_{0}({\bf{\Theta}}).
Recalling the notations in Table I, we rewrite f0​(𝚯)subscript𝑓0𝚯f_{0}({\bf{\Theta}}) as a function of 𝐯𝐯\bf{v}, i.e., h0​(𝐯)subscriptℎ0𝐯{h_{0}}({\bf{v}}):

S5.T2.caption: TABLE II: Simulation Parameters
S5.T2.table:
Parameter Value
Number of devices K=3𝐾3K=3
Number of antennas at the BS
Nr=16subscript𝑁𝑟16N_{r}=16

Nt=2subscript𝑁𝑡2N_{t}=2

p^gap=10subscript^𝑝gap10{\hat{p}}_{\rm gap}=10 dBm,
p~gap=17subscript~𝑝gap17{\tilde{p}}_{\rm gap}=17 dBm

references:
In the simulation, the devices are uniformly randomly distributed in a square area of 100×100100100100\times 100 m2 on the ground.
The three-dimensional coordinates of the BS and RIS are (0,0,25)0025(0,0,25) m and (20,20,20)202020(20,20,20) m, respectively.
The path loss is L=C0​(d/D0)−ν𝐿subscript𝐶0superscript𝑑subscript𝐷0𝜈L={C_{0}}({d}/{D_{0}})^{-\nu}, where C0subscript𝐶0C_{0} denotes the path loss at the reference distance D0=1subscript𝐷01D_{0}=1 m and C0=0​dBmsubscript𝐶00dBmC_{0}=0~{}\text{dBm} by default, d𝑑d is the distance between the transmitter and receiver, and ν𝜈\nu is the path loss exponent.
The path loss exponents from the devices to the BS, from the devices to the RIS, and from the RIS to the BS are set to νd​b=3.2subscript𝜈𝑑𝑏3.2\nu_{db}=3.2, νd​r=2.6subscript𝜈𝑑𝑟2.6\nu_{dr}=2.6, and νr​b=2.2subscript𝜈𝑟𝑏2.2\nu_{rb}=2.2, respectively.
We consider Rician fading between the devices and RIS, and between the RIS and BS with the Rician factors of κd​r=10subscript𝜅𝑑𝑟10\kappa_{dr}=10 and κr​b=10subscript𝜅𝑟𝑏10\kappa_{rb}=10, respectively.
Two scenarios are considered between the devices and BS.
In the first scenario, we consider the Rician fading with Rician factor κd​b=2subscript𝜅𝑑𝑏2\kappa_{db}=2.
In the second scenario, we consider the Rayleigh fading to emulate the situation where the devices are located in blind spots, i.e., the LoS paths from the devices to the BS are blocked.
The channel estimation errors are measured by the NMSE ι=𝔼​[‖𝐇−𝐇^‖F2]/𝔼​[‖𝐇^‖F2]𝜄𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐇^𝐇𝐹2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm^𝐇𝐹2\iota=\mathbb{E}[\|{\bf{H}}-{\widehat{\bf{H}}}\|_{F}^{2}]/\mathbb{E}[\|{\widehat{\bf{H}}}\|_{F}^{2}], over all links [18].
ι=0𝜄0\iota=0 indicates perfect CSI.
Unless otherwise specified, other parameters are listed in Table II.
